full_title_en: Maternal-Fetal Hemorrhage Rh(D) Immune Globulin Dosage
medium_description_en: Calculates amount of RhIG to be administered to the mother, at the time of delivery, to prevent hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).
before_use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a clinical pathologist or pharmacist when necessary.

seo.meta_description_en: The RhIG Dosing tool calculates amount of RhIG to be administered to the mother to prevent hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).

how_to_use.use_case_en: This calculator should be used to compute the number of RhIG vials to administer to an Rh-negative mother who has not yet developed an anti-D, when she gives birth to an Rh-positive child.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Calculation of maternal blood volume is an estimation using Nadler’s equation.
  • Fetal cell percentage can be obtained by both flow cytometry or Kleihauer-Betke methodology.
how_to_use.why_use_en: When a mother who is Rh-negative gives birth to a baby who is Rh-positive, there is a possibility that the mother could develop an antibody to the D antigen due to mixing of fetal and maternal blood. The presence of an anti-D leads to a potential risk for HDFN in future pregnancies. Therefore, to prevent HDFN and the formation of an anti-D in the mother, RhIG is given to the mother at 28 weeks and after birth. The amount of RhIG given to the mother after birth is dependent on the amount of fetal-maternal hemorrhage. This formula calculates the amount of fetal-maternal hemorrhage as well as the number of RhIG vials be given to the mother.

next_steps.advice_en: RhIG should be given to the mother at 28 weeks and after birth.

about.formula_en:
Number of RhIG vials = fetal cells/total cells counted × maternal blood volume, mL / 30 mL

Then, round to the nearest whole number and add 1.

Example:

  • Flow cytometry of fetal cells in maternal blood stream = 1.7%
  • Total maternal blood volume = 3,700 mL
  • Volume of fetal blood in maternal blood stream = 3,700 x 0.017 = 62.9 mL
  • Number of RhIG vials = 62.9 / 30 = 2.1 vials --> round down to 2 and add 1
  • RhIG vials to administer = 3 vials

Original/Primary Reference.text: Kennedy, M, Delaney M, Scrape S. Perinatal issues in transfusion practice. In: Fung M, Grossman B, Hillyer C, Westhoff C, eds. Technical Manual.18th ed. Bethesda, MD: AABB; 2014:561–569.

expert_name.description: Ronald "George" Hauser, MD, is an assistant professor in laboratory medicine at Yale University School of Medicine who splits his time between clinical medicine and informatics research. As an attending physician, he practices medicine at the interface between other clinicians and the clinical laboratories, which include Chemistry, Hematology, Microbiology, and the Blood Bank. He also works along with medical residents, particularly at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in West Haven, Connecticut. He practices clinical informatics for various projects affiliated at Yale University and the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) including the Recipient Epidemiology and Donor Evaluation Study (REDS; Yale, NIH) and the HIV, Hepatitis, and Related Conditions program (VHA).
